Thanks so much for this patch!  I didn't know that adding log rotation was so easy

This looks like your changes will apply very cleanly, but in thinking towards future releases of Maid, I'm wondering if there should be a spec backing it up so I don't break it by accident.

It would seem that something like https://github.com/defunkt/fakefs could make this really easy.  Would you be willing to take a stab at this?  If it isn't feasible, please let me know, and I'll be happy to complete the pull request without.

Thanks again!

Ben

Hey man, cool, i'd love to take a stab at it, i love playing with new
tech. I'll let you know how it goes.

~//M

Hi @macfidelity,

Thanks for posting this issue; I'm happy you find Maid interesting.  The issue you mentioned is something I'd definitely like to improve, as I'm gradually switching from using Mac OS X to using Ubuntu.

The methods that are specific to OS X are listed [in the documentation](http://rubydoc.info/gems/maid/0.1.0/Maid/Tools).  They are tagged with "Mac OS X".  For the time being, it would be best to avoid them.

There's [some code to detect whether the host OS supports a given command](https://github.com/benjaminoakes/maid/blob/master/lib/maid/maid.rb#L92), but clearly it's less than foolproof.  As a longer term strategy, I'd like to have feature parity between OS X and Ubuntu (if possible).

I'm open to alternatives, as well of course.  :smile:

Best wishes,

Ben

Hey guys,

Sorry about that; this confusion came up because I decided to change the default command from `clean` to `help`.

Why?  It's better to be safe than sorry:  I found that I was running rules accidentally far too many times.  I really didn't want that to affect someone that didn't know the default behavior (and was just trying to see if `maid` was still installed, etc).  I considered that a bug that needed to be fixed, especially as running the sample rules could have unintended consequences.

Back to this issue:  any time that you used `maid` to start cleaning before, you'll need to do `maid clean` now.  It's a change, but I think a change for the better, given the above problem.  However, I hadn't run through the examples in the README; I just updated them.

(In retrospect, Maid 0.1.2 might have been better named 0.2.0 according to [semantic versioning](http://semver.org/).  I'm going to try to adhere to that more closely in the future.)

Given the amount of people that have recently started using Maid, I'd like to start making beta releases before making stable releases.  Please see issue #10 for more info.

Thanks again for using Maid!  It's great to see that so many people are interested in it.

Ben
Closing, as I think the question has been answered.  Please feel free to reopen if needed.

I think it would make sense to abstract this.  Perhaps a method like:

``` ruby
def spotlight_attribute(attr_name)
  # ...
end
```

The other Spotlight-related methods could make it easier to use, but if you needed to refer to an uncommon Spotlight attribute, it would still be possible by having this method.

Having this method would make it possible to refer to uncommon Spotlight attributes.  The other Spotlight-related methods would still be good to make it a little easier (but could still call `spotlight_attribute` internally).

The above may not be possible, but something along those lines.

I like to send stuff to the trash, but for the big files (films, db_dumps, etc.) I want to just remove them outright.  I have already updated the trash task to take a size option.  As I was doing research into removal, it dawned on me that a remove tool would be a good alternative (See #30).  I can make this separate, but the functionality from remove would just get duplicated during the check.

I'll be merging this into the just-pushed `simple-tools` branch, which is the milestone this will go under.  (I want to get some bugfixes out first.)  Could you choose that as the target if you make more pull requests, please?  I just added a note to that effect to the wiki; I should have done that last night.  :smile:

Thanks again!  It's very appreciated.

For now, it seems like `remove` would handle a lot of the cases...

Are you thinking that `trash` would work something like this?

``` ruby
# Psuedo-code:
def trash(path, opts = {})
  if opts[:removal_threshold] && disk_usage(path) > opts[:removal_threshold]
    remove(path)
  else
    # normal trash logic
  end
end
```

Then it could be called like so:

``` ruby
trash('~/Downloads/*.m4v', removal_threshold: 2.gigabytes)
```

We'd need to be somewhat careful with this; a bug in the implementation could be bad news (e.g. a lot more files get deleted than you think...).

Great.  I think the roadmap will be:
1. `bugfixes` (maybe combined with `update-deps`), probably to be called v0.1.3
2. `simple-tools`, probably called v0.1.4, unless there are interface changes, then v0.2.0

The timeframe is roughly "when they're done".  :smile:

@benjaminoakes:
i did install trash-cli (Installed: 0.11.3~git20120324.fb57a8e-1) via apt for a first quick-test (without using maid) on my 12.04 ubuntu box. the trash-list commands outputs the content of my user trash correct. Trash-put seems to work as well as i expected - same goes for restore-trash and trash-empty. 

Looks interesting so far to me. 

anything in particular you would like to have tested with it

Since Maid essentially does a `mv` call, I'm interested in how well that actually works...

This is basically what Maid will do after the bugfix:

``` bash
mv foo.txt "$HOME/.local/share/Trash"
```

I'd want to know if:
- ...you can see the file in Nautilus' Trash
- ...you can restore the file in Nautilus' Trash
- ...you can see the file in `trash-list`
- ...you can restore the file via `restore-trash`
- ...things always work in the way you'd expect?  (E.g., does it act differently with folders?)
- ...duplicate names are handled differently.  (E.g., do the commands above again... do you have two `foo.txt` or just one?)

If you'd like to check that out, that'd would be very helpful!  Otherwise, I'll come back to it sometime... maybe even next week.

**Sidebar:** Since we're trashing things to `~/.Trash` on Ubuntu, there will probably be a migration step where they all get moved to the right place when `v0.1.3` ("trash-bugfixes" milestone) comes out.  That would probably be easy to do, but I'm not sure of all the implications yet.  It would be something like this:

``` bash
mv ~/.Trash/* "$HOME/.local/share/Trash"
rmdir ~/.Trash
```
exactly, what i was thinking.

Ok.

I created a file 'foo.txt' and executed the following command manually to simulate the bugfixed coming maid version (if i understood you correct)

> mv foo.txt "$HOME/.local/share/Trash"

As a result the trashed file was not visible in my trash bin - but if i do change the command to:

> mv foo.txt "$HOME/.local/share/Trash/files"

I am able to see the trashed file in my nautilus trash. 

Seems like inside $HOME/.local/share/Trash is some kind of sub-folder-structure which i don't fully know/understand so far ...but 'files' seems to be the relevant subfolder for the deleted files.

Restoring that file via nautilus itself using the 'restore selected items' button was not possible as it resulted in the following error:

> Could not determine original location of 'foo.txt'.
> The item cannot be restored from trash.

while i was able to drag the file from nautilus -> trash folder as expected to whatever place i wanted to restore it like that.

trash-list does not list the mv'ed file either.
i stopped that quick test at this point and did something else:
1. created foo.txt again
2. deleted foo.txt using the nautilus function
3. checked content of "$HOME/.local/share/Trash"

and it seems like the trash folder subfolders do work somehow like that:
- expunged (not clear)
- files (contains the actual deleted files and folders - if deleted using naultils move to trash function)
- info (contains a .trashinfo file for each deleted file/folder which contains the original location and timestamp of the delete action.

my conclusion (without having tested it fully)
- maid should move the files to "$HOME/.local/share/Trash/files" NOT to "$HOME/.local/share/Trash"
- maid needs to create a .trashinfo file for each moved file/folder in "$HOME/.local/share/Trash/info" as i.e. trash-list seems to rely on it

i guess it would make sense to double-check that and then maybe add a routine/function for the .trashinfo files in the info subfolder to be able to test further. any other ideas?

all this was tested on Ubuntu 12.04 - havent considered anything mac-specific here.

@macfidelity Thank you for looking at that!  It's a great help.

I'm a little uncomfortable writing something to modify `.trashinfo`.  That seems to go farther into OS details than Maid probably should.

What might get implemented is:
- If you have `trash-put` available, delegate to it.
- If not, move to `$XDG_DATA_HOME/Trash/files` (see [Why Is There No More `~/.Trash`?](http://www.faqoverflow.com/askubuntu/13779.html)).  The user will have access to the file, but no "restore" functionality.

The former case could be made easier with an Ubuntu package (#3) -- it could just install `trash-cli` as a dependency.

I'm still thinking about it, but the above steps would be easier to write than anything else I'm thinking of... 

**Bare minimum,** we'll at least move to `$XDG_DATA_HOME/Trash/files` to get the bug fixed.

This looks great, thanks!  I'm merging.

I'm going to refactor it a little.

``` ruby
paths = [paths] unless paths.kind_of?(Array)
paths.each # ...
```

Ruby provides an "arrayification operator", which [Avdi Grimm introduced me to at RubyConf](http://avdi.org/talks/confident-code-railsconf-2011/) (slide 23).  It does basically the same thing as the above, but more compactly:

``` ruby
Array(paths).each # ...
```

After a quick glance, this seems good, but I'd like to think about it a little longer.  It's getting a little late over here.  :smile:

In the meantime:
- I would prefer the C-style operators (`&&` and `!`) vs `and`/`not`.  (See also https://github.com/bbatsov/ruby-style-guide)  Could you change them please?
- `trash('foo.zip', remove: 1.gigabyte)` doesn't read quite as well as I'd like (although I like the brevity).  How about...  `trash('foo.zip', remove_over: 1.gigabyte)`?  I'm open to alternatives.
- Especially since `disk_usage` shells out and then parses the result, I'm a little nervous about files getting removed accidentally.  (I'm not sure how realistic that is, but Maid is automatically handling people's files, after all.)  Perhaps [a pure-Ruby solution](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/3632074/what-is-the-fastest-way-to-calculate-disk-usage-per-customer)?  I'm still on the fence here.

Hi Larry,

Thanks for your contribution.  It's very appreciated!

However, this implementation isn't entirely what I had in mind.  My apologies; the description of #27 is a little misleading.  The idea here isn't to just make `find` give the same output as `dir`, but rather _act like_ `dir` in that it gives back an `Array`.  (The calls `dir('~/Downloads')` and `find('~/Downloads')` should give quite different results.  :smile:)

My thought was that `find` could be modified to have a default block that collects the names of the files (and then that is used as the result).

Also, if possible, please make this a pull request for the `simple-tools` branch, as that's going to be used for the future release.  If it's easier to leave it on `master`, that's fine too.  I'll be happy to merge it.  :smile:

Thanks again for your work on this.  I'm sorry the intent was miscommunicated!

Best wishes,

Ben

Hi @choupachupss,

Thanks for writing in!  `find` does need some better documentation.  Better documentation is a goal for Maid v0.2.0 (hopefully released this coming weekend), so I'll be keeping this in mind.  You can check out the new docs here:  https://github.com/benjaminoakes/maid/blob/master/lib/maid/tools.rb#L196.  Additionally, you're very welcome to contribute tips and tricks to [the wiki](https://github.com/benjaminoakes/maid/wiki).

However, `find` is kind of odd in that it's been less useful to me than I would have originally thought... and it tends to confuse things.  In fact, it's actually not necessary in the rule you brought up.  I would write it slightly differently, since `dir` just gives back an `Array`:

``` ruby
rule 'facebookPhoto' do
  paths = dir('~/Downloads/*.jpg').select { |p| p.match(/[a-zA-Z]*/) }
  move(paths, '~/Images/')
end
```

But that's a pretty common pattern, so Ruby actually gives you `Array#grep` to make it simpler:

``` ruby
rule 'facebookPhoto' do
  move(dir('~/Downloads/*.jpg').grep(/[a-zA-Z]*/), '~/Images/')
end
```

(Note: if I'm interpreting the intention of your rule correctly, that regexp may need a little tweaking.)

I hope that helps!  Thanks again for using Maid.

Ben

It would be nice to be able to memoize `checksum_for`, but since rules have the ability to change the state of files while evaluating, that would be next to impossible to invalidate properly.

You could make it even more expressive with a few additions:

``` rb
Maid.rules do
  def all_but_the_oldest(paths)
    files(paths).sort_by { |f| File.mtime(f) }[1..-1]
  end

  def all_but_the_newest(paths)
    file(paths).sort_by { |f| File.mtime(f) }[0..-2]
  end

  def all_but_the_longest(paths)
    file(paths).sort_by { |f| File.basename(f).length }[0..-2]
  end

  def all_but_the_shortest(paths)
    file(paths).sort_by { |f| File.basename(f).length }[1..-1]
  end

  rule 'Trash duplicate downloads' do
    dupes_in('~/Downloads/*').each do |dupes|
      # Keep the dupe with the shortest filename
      trash all_but_the_shortest dupes

      # You could also keep the oldest:
      trash all_but_the_oldest dupes
    end
  end
end
```

I really like how `dupes_in` and `trash all_but_the_oldest dupes` reads... but I've been wondering if there's another way to express this filtering logic in a more reusable way.  I don't have a fully formed idea about that yet, however.

Rather than having additional purpose-built methods for this, could we take advantage of what `Array` and `Enumerable` give us?

Some pseudo-code variations on that idea:

``` ruby
trash dir('*.png').select(&file?) # Or `trash dir('*.png').select(&files)`
trash dir('*.png').select(&directory?)
trash dir('*.png').reject(&oldest) # Same as all_but_the_oldest
trash dir('*.png').reject(&newest) # Same as all_but_the_newest
trash dir('*.png').map(&modified_at).max
trash dir('*.png').grep(/foo/).reject(&shortest_name)

trash dupes.reject(&oldest)
trash dupes.reject(&shortest_name)
```

Include `all_but_the_oldest` and friends would definitely **not** hold up any pull request, but filtering arrays of filenames a serious thing to consider if we want code to be reusable in interesting ways.  I'd appreciate your opinion on this.  Food for thought if nothing else.  :smile:

WIth the file command, we can get the mimetype. For example `file -b --mime-type example.jpg` returns `image/jpeg`.

I'd be happy to write a mimetype method and maybe a method that just returns the media_type. So, we can target image, video or other media types.

I think the spotlight content_types method could still provide value to OS X users, though. The mimetype of a zip is `application/zip`, which is not as helpful for targeting general types as `public.archive` provided by spotlight.

There may be way to get a tree of types on Linux, but I don't know how.

I could certainly see including both solutions.  People have requested having more Spotlight attributes (e.g., #12) before, and I can definitely understand the usefulness of that.  (Note: [`ruby-spotlight`](https://github.com/youpy/ruby-spotlight) might be a big help, but may not be necessary right now.)

However, if  we generalize that Spotlight feature, it might be a big win.  For example, instead of only adding `content_types()`, we could do something like:

``` ruby
# Get the kMDItemContentType for the path, converting to camel case like I do in Vertigo:
#
#     # something like this:
#     name.to_s.gsub(/_([a-z])/) { $1.upcase }
#
# https://github.com/benjaminoakes/vertigo/blob/develop/lib/vertigo/client.rb#L78
spotlight_attribute(path, :item_content_type)

# It's general, so you could get other attributes like kMDItemAuthors:
spotlight_attribute(path, :item_authors)
```

Regarding mime types, I'd like to avoid shelling out to use more system commands (e.g. `file`).  If we can use `MIME::Types.type_for('citydesk.xml')` to the same effect with a well tested `Ruby` library, that has less room for error in my experience.  But like I said, I don't know a lot of what the `mime-types` gem has in its API.

Thanks again for your help on this!  I was honestly thinking mime types were the way to go before this conversation, but I can certainly see how the Spotlight metadata would be useful now.

Adding groups would help with this as well:

```
maid clean -n --group downloads
```

``` rb
group :downloads do
  rule 'Trash duplicate downloads' do
    dupes_in('~/Downloads/*').each do |dupes|
      trash dupes.sort_by { |p| File.basename(p).length }[1..-1]
    end
  end

  rule 'Trash old files downloaded while developing/testing' do
    files('~/Downloads/*').each do |path|
      if downloaded_from(path).any? { |u| u.match %r{//(localhost|[^\.]+\.dev)} } and 1.week.since? accessed_at path
        trash path
      end
    end
  end

  rule 'Trash zips and tarballs downloaded from GitHub' do
    dir('~/Downloads/*.{zip,tgz,gz,rar,tar}').each do |path|
      if downloaded_from(path).any? { |u| u.match %r{//([^\/]+\.)?github\.com\/} }
        trash path
      end
    end
  end
end
```

@benjaminoakes Sorry for the late response. Added a simple README section and rebased:

### Running as a daemon

To run Maid as a daemon you first have to specify watch/repeat rules.

They are defined like this:

``` ruby
repeat '1s' do
  rule 'This rule will run every second' do
    # some task
  end
end

watch '/home/user/Downloads' do
  rule 'This rule will run on every change to the downloads directory' do
    # another task
  end
end
```

To run the daemon run `maid daemon`

I would like to try this one, if it’s possible. I was just wondering if you have any ideas of how you would approach to this. I mean, not the task definition API itself, which was made clear in your example, but how to execute those instructions. 

My idea was to instantiate a `Maid`, wrap those instructions in a rule, and then call `#clean` on that instance. That way it wouldn’t change anything in the execution flow of a task (logging it properly etc.).

Basically the problem here was that the rules were ran within the Watch/Repeat instance scope. So they had no way to access the utility functions. As the utility functions use some facilities from the Maid class, the best way to fix this was to run the rules with instance_exec on the Maid instance.

I've been having the same issue.  Although for me it seems to be about once a week.  Looking through system logs and don't see anything happening at that time.  If it really is happening on directory listing there's some dtrace commands that you can run to see what process is accessing it.

```
sudo opensnoop -a -f /Users/yourname/Desktop/some-file-that-access-time-changes-a-lot
```

Problem is that slows down all file access calls.  For example creating a new tab in terminal takes several seconds where it's near instant if opensnoop isn't running.  For my case (weekly but not exactly weekly) running opensnoop until then isn't possible.  Another fun command is `sudo iosnoop -vstoD` which will show every kind (both read/write) of access for every file in the system.  Needless to say it's rather verbose but it may show a pattern.

My workaround has been to be more aggressive in the checking.  For example after 2 days screen shots are moved out of desktop (I don't delete anything so it's not a big deal to move it sooner)

I have a few guidelines:
- Any solution must work on Linux.  By that, I mean `maid` can't fail to install just because of OSX specific code existing to support the OSX-only tagging feature.  To be clear, we **don't** need to have the exact same featureset on Linux.
- From looking at [jdberry/tag](https://github.com/jdberry/tag/), it seems like a Ruby gem that wraps it could be a very good idea.  I don't know much about taking that approach, but looking at `rb-fsevent` could be a good starting point.

Awesome, thank you!

Adding to `tools.rb` is the only requirement, but specs would be appreciated of course if you have time.  Also, there's a lot of great stuff in your `rules.rb` besides the "tag" code.  All of the utility methods you wrote would be welcome.

As for Linux users, I think we can just report that tagging isn't available since it's an OSX-only feature.  The `Maid::Platform.osx?` command is available to check what platform `maid` is running on.

In pseudo code:

```
if Maid::Platform.osx?
  if has_tag_available?
    cmd(...)
  else
    print "To use this feature, you need `tag` installed.  Run `brew install tag`"
  end
else
  print "sorry, tagging is unavailable on your platform"
end
```

Here is the documentation for creating a new Formula in home brew. 

https://github.com/Homebrew/brew/blob/master/docs/Formula-Cookbook.md#formula-cookbook

Brew does have the ability to install rubygems as homebrew formulae. You just need to install the brew-gem formula with:

`brew install brew-gem`

After that you can install Ruby gems through homebrew with (to install maid for example):

`brew gem install maid`

**Otherwise**, if people are more in favor of an actual Homebrew formula for installing, the Brew formula should be rather simple (since the formula will use gem to install Maid). Something like this, to start with:

```
require 'formula'

class BrewMaid < Formula
  homepage 'https://github.com/benjaminoakes/maid/'

  def initialize(*args)
    @name = "maid"
    @version = "0.7.0"
    super
  end

  def install
    system "gem", "install", name, "--version", version, "--install-dir", prefix
  end
end
```

As I continued other personal projects, I encountered some similar symptoms and it turns out, **macOS(and iOS) would not normalize unicode character on OS level** while Windows do.
